turns.content: is Alger Hiss a soviet spy

Alger Hiss was a former US State Department official who was accused of being a Soviet spy during the Cold War era. The allegations against Hiss were first made by a former Soviet spy named Whittaker Chambers in 1948, and Hiss was subsequently tried and convicted of perjury in 1950 for denying these allegations.

The case against Hiss was controversial and remains so to this day. Some historians and researchers believe that Hiss was indeed a Soviet spy, while others believe that he was falsely accused and convicted.

The evidence against Hiss largely consisted of testimony from Chambers, who claimed that Hiss had provided him with classified documents and information during the 1930s. Hiss denied these allegations and maintained his innocence throughout his trial and subsequent appeals.

In recent years, some new evidence has come to light that has cast doubt on Hiss's guilt. For example, in the 1990s, declassified Soviet intelligence files revealed that Hiss had been identified by Soviet spies as a potential recruit, but there was no evidence that he had actually provided them with any classified information.

Overall, while the case against Hiss is complex and contentious, there is significant evidence to suggest that he was at least involved in some way with Soviet espionage activities. However, the full extent of his involvement remains a matter of debate among historians and researchers.

It is difficult to provide a simple "yes" or "no" answer to the question of whether Alger Hiss was a Soviet spy, as the evidence is complex and contentious.
